it's hard to install those package
when a file ends in .tar.gz, think about it like a .zip file in windows. You "unzip" it by running "tar zxvf filename.tar.gz" and then you can get at the contents

usually, installable files that end in .tar.gz is the source code that you're going to have to compile. You decompress it, go in. There's usually a readme file that will give you the info you need on how to compile and install it
yes. you can also extract it using file-roller by doubleclicking on it from the GUI

like I said, after you extract the files, you need to go into the directory that has been extracted. There should be a README file for installing the program from source if it's a program you're trying to install
depends on what it is. almost always, .tar.gz is source code for a program, and there isn't an automated process to install it.
wait, you're installing vmware? why don't you just use synaptic?
so you shouldn't need that .tar.gz file
it worked right out of the box? that's pretty impressive
well, virtual machines are always a lot slower than an OS directly installed on a computer
